results.title: School's in, Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Martyn Down, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Russian Education”.
Examines the present school system in the Soviet Union. Demonstrates the style of Soviet teaching which is fairly rigid and formal, with the emphasis on teacher dominated instruction and passive pupils, responding only when instructed to do so. A more flexible teaching style was introduced some years ago but was later abandoned. Photographer, Dean Semler; script, Roger Milliss; editor, Martyn Down; sound, George Hart, Howard Spry; commentator, Margaret Throsby.

results.title: Working: Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Soviet style”.
A look at the Soviet economy in the 1970’s. Examines some of the Industrial developments, investigates output, productivity, the relationships between management and the trade unions, and management and individual workers. Also examines working conditions and salaries in a coal mine, a refrigerator factory, a timber processing complex, and dock workers in Odessa

results.title: Science international. No. 2. The last scourge
results.creator_credit: Aubrey F Singer, Humphrey Fisher and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: A report on the world-wide investigations into the origins of life, as revealed in the study of the cell, and progress in the battle against cancer. British, American, French and Russian scientists tell of current lines of research into the origins of cancer in the light of what has already been discovered about the cell. The clinical aspects of cancer are not dealt with.

results.title: Scenes and songs from Boyd Webb
results.creator_credit: Boyd Webb, Philip Haas, Arts Council of Great Britain and Methodact
results.brief_description: Boyd Webb is usually classified as a sculptor although he does not exhibit three-dimensional objects. His art-works are extremely large photographs. In this film, the artist has designed eight new works specifically for the film camera. They expand on recent photographic pieces which have dealt with the vagaries of life in a post-nuclear era.

results.title: People of influence
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, John Abbott, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Soviet style”.
The troika, which governs the lives of all working Russians is illustrated. The film shows the relationship between the Director, the Trade Union chairman and the Party secretary of an enterprise. The Director of the enterprise is shown at a coal mine, supervising his men; the Party Secretary’s influence aids the workers in a gravel washing enterprise; a Trade Union Chairman is seen at work at a refrigerator factory and shows her responsibilities. Cameraman, Dean Semler; editors, Tom Foley, Wayne Le Clos.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arch Nicholson, John Abbott, Tom Manefield and Film Australia

results.title: When the war came to Australia
results.creator_credit: Bee Reynolds, Will Davies, Peter Butt and Look Television Productions
results.brief_description: A four-part series which looks at world war two from the point of view of ordinary Australians. Australians who either took part in the war or observed it from home, talk about their experiences in between archival footage and narrated commentary.

results.title: The Long war
results.creator_credit: Peter Butt, Bee Reynolds, Will Davies and Look Television Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “When the war came to Australia”.
In this final episode, Australians must face the consequences of over six years of war - a toll of shattered limbs, lives and unrealised dreams. After victory in the Pacific, it is a weary nation that welcomes its soldiers home. The war years have changed for ever the way Australians see themselves, both individually, particularly with respect to the relationships between the sexes, and as a nation looking to America and Asia instead of to Britain. Individuals comment on what the war meant to the average Aussie and how it affected their lives.

results.title: Saviours, heroes, lovers
results.creator_credit: Peter Butt, Bee Reynolds, Will Davies and Look Television Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “When the war came to Australia”.
The Americans arrive and the Australians welcome them into their homes and into their lives. The Australian women are charmed but when the Australian soldiers arrive home from Europe they are less than pleased. General MacArthur takes over the Pacific war which causes some resentment. Normal life is put on hold as the men are away and women work longer hours. Life is hard with little leisure and the mounting toll of the dead and wounded is making an impact.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Butt, Bee Reynolds, Will Davies and Look Television Productions

results.title: Our darkest hour
results.creator_credit: Peter Butt, Bee Reynolds, Will Davies and Look Television Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “When the war came to Australia”.
The true horror of war hits Australia as the Japanese attack and bomb Darwin. Britain’s failure to defend Singapore betrays Australia’s long held belief that the Mother Country will always come to her defence. Prime Minister John Curtin begins to rally the nation and the Americans arrive. Features reminiscences from those who lived through the experience, including Russell Braddon and Dorothy Hewett.
